As part of our holistic approach to education, North Shore Coaching College offers students an opportunity to participate in Competitions and Assessments run by prestigious organisations worldwide. Some include the following:
Nearest station Melton Train station 3.4 kms away. Take 456 Bus from Melton station.

We are proud to announce that North Shore Coaching College is an authorised Testing Centre for the CAT Competition, administered by the Australian Maths Trust (AMT), which is under the Trusteeship of the University of Canberra.

The CAT competition is a one-hour problem solving competition designed to encourage student curiosity and promote multiple modes of thinking. The CAT has four divisions: Upper Primary (years 5–6), Junior (years 7–8), Intermediate (years 9–10) and Senior (years 11–12). Your child is invited to participate through North Shore Coaching College, and we will shortly have more information for enrolment into CAT Competition 2020.
Complete the Enrolment Form and return as per the instructions on the form.

What is the HSC? HSC is a short form for Higher School Certificate administered by The NSW Department of Education. It is an examination for Year 12 students and the …
HSC is a short form for Higher School Certificate administered by

. It is an examination for Year 12 students and the results are crucial in determining whether a student can get into the university of their choice or not. HSC has undergone a number of major changes since World War II and the latest major change started in 2016 and will be fully implemented in 2020.

All participants in the HSC exam will receive a certificate stating what subjects they have taken and what marks. One distinct feature of the certificate is that there is no “pass/fail” marks. Thus we may see the certificate as a record of what and how well the student has done rather than the attainment of a certain standard.
As mentioned earlier, there are not pass/fail mark. To obtain this certificate, there are three essential requirements:
b) Study minimum of 12 units* in Year 11, and
c) Study minimum of 10 units in Year 12

The term 'unit' is a historical term used to refer to the 'size' or efforts required for that subject. The larger the number, the harder/more time-consuming the subject is. Since 2001, it is not relevant any more because most subjects are standardised to 2 units with harder subjects described as 'extension'. Thus 3 unit English is broken down into two subjects: 2 unit Advanced English and 1 unit Extension English.
Since most subjects are 2 units, we can conceptually say students need to study 6 subjects in Year 11 and only 5 subjects in Year 12.

There are around 100 subjects that students can choose to study in their final two years of high school, namely Year 11 and 12. There is only ONE compulsory subject, English, which can be taken at several levels. The easiest form is EAL/D specially designed for students recently (less than four years) who have come to Australia to study. The most popular level is Standard with over 50% of Year 12 students taking this level. If a student is good in English, then he/she should take the more challenging Advanced English. Over 90% of subjects are 2 units with the rest mostly Extension units.

The final HSC mark for each subject comprises of two components: Examination mark and Assessment mark, of equal important, i.e. 50-50. Examination mark is what students get from the external HSC examination. Assessment mark is what the schools give to each of their students, subject-by-subject. Conceptually, before sitting for the HSC examination, half of the HSC mark has already been determined (by teachers). Thus in order to get high HSC mark, students must do well in their school as well as do well in the external exam. The Assessment marks are accumulated during the last 4 terms before the HSC examination, i.e. Year 11 term 4, Year 12 terms 1,2, and 3. For this reason, most schools label Year 11 term 4 as Year 12.
There are many strategies in addition to studying hard. The following are some more important ones:

a) Pay attention early: Because Assessment marks are accumulated in the last 4 terms before the actual examination, a student must pay attention in school work including homework, assessments, projects, behaviour in class, etc. Do not leave things to the last minutes. It will be too late to change the perception of your teacher.

b) Choose subjects wisely: HSC subjects are chosen by students late in term 2 or beginning of term 3 of Year 10. Take extra care in those choices because once those subjects are chosen, students are stuck with them for the next two years. Changing subjects is quite difficult and a terrible waste of time, (for more details, refer to our upcoming Year 10 Subject Choice blog article).

c) Time management: Since most students need to study a minimum of 5 subjects, it is advisable to spread their time more evenly across those subjects. It is much easier to improve from 60 marks to 70 but it would be much much harder to improve from 90 to 100 and sometimes impossible. Thus it is tactically wrong to spend half of one’s study time to one subject and do really well while letting the other four subjects languishing.

As mentioned earlier, the certificate is only a record of what and how well a student has done in HSC. It is great if a student can get high marks in their HSC but that alone will not ensure a place in the top universities. University entrance is largely based on another number called ATAR.

Any parent, teacher or student who is unwell should not attend class and should seek medical attention as soon as possible. We also recommend that you follow the national and state department health alerts and in particular to:
As an additional safety precaution, we will be providing alcohol-based hand rubs at the North Shore office.

致各位家长，员工，老师和同学们：
因应新型冠状病毒感染情况的最新发展, 澳大利亚政府修订并更新了有关应对新型冠状病毒(COVID-19)的管制措施指引。
为了尽量减低病毒传播风险，
本学院呼吁近期从中国（包括香港）及伊朗返澳的家长，员工，老师和同学们，请于回澳后至少14天，暂时停止进入北岸进修学院各校舍上课。
北岸进修学院会密切留意澳洲政府及各省卫生局的最新健康警报与指引。
各位／任何身体不适者均不应上课或上班，并尽快求医。我校亦建议您配合澳洲政府和各省卫生局颁布最新的健康指引，包括：
本学院的接待处亦会提供酒精类搓手液为预防措施。
若学生在校舍内感到不适，我们将立即与家长联系，并希望家长能尽快接送子女回家休息，有必要时须寻求医疗协助。
北岸进修学院常务董事 谨启

Much has been said and written about the role of tuition in the life of a child. It is a topic that can prove controversial and will always lead to lively debate.

Whilst very popular overseas, the idea of academic tuition for primary school students was virtually unknown in Australia a generation ago. The widely held view was that children did not need to spend any time outside of school hours undertaking more study except for the occasional homework assignment. That view has changed dramatically in the past three decades as the world demands more of us all and especially our children.

It was thought that children would ‘lose their childhood’ if they were required to undertake further study. Children who did undertake further study were considered to be like ‘robots’; drained of joy and creativity by overbearing parents. It was easy for this myth to spread in a country that places high regard on recreational activity and ‘living for the weekend’.

However, the loss of childhood is a myth. In the 20 years I have been with North Shore I have seen students filled with vibrancy, joy and creativity. Observation of any classroom reveals a sea of happy faces engaged in learning.

In ensuring a child has a firm educational foundation, of which tutoring plays an important part, there is room for a myriad of cultural, sporting, spiritual and recreational activities. If anything I would propose that North Shore students are more successful in the arts and sport than the average student population.

Over recent years many of our students have competed at the state and national level in a variety of sports, performed as solo or ensemble performers at the Opera House, won numerous eisteddfod events, won national poetry competitions……….

Tuition is an integral part of a successful life – the misconception that students who attend coaching have no life, no outside interests is one that does not stack up to the evidence. We seek to offer beyond what your child’s school is offering. Not to compete with their school but to supplement their education.

You have the most important job ever entrusted to a human being: that of being a parent. Your desire to ensure your child has the strongest foundations for a successful and prosperous life is your ultimate task. Tuition is an important element in this preparation.

I am first and foremost an educator, committed to bettering the lives of children through quality educational experiences. To rob a child of their love of learning is anathema to me. I make no apology for the success North Shore has brought thousands of students across this great country. I am proud to be part of the North Shore Coaching College because quality tuition changes lives. It ensures your child a brighter future.

Providing an environment where children can learn, be inspired and learn to love learning is the goal to which the North Shore Coaching College aspires. We want our students to look back with fond memories of their time with us.
At North Shore we remain ever respectful of our obligation to you and your children. A brighter future awaits those who have a better life because of tuition.

At North Shore Coaching College we pride ourselves on fostering each child’s potential in academia and personal skills. We are committed to advance students’ knowledge, confidence and success through “face to face” coaching and tuition to develop globally-aware and culturally knowledgeable students in an increasingly digital world where personal communication is diminishing.
“To me, a great educator inspires dreams, encourages creativity, builds confidence and instils a love of learning providing a solid foundation for success as lifelong learners.”
When I started our first North Shore tuition centre at Chatswood, NSW in 1991, I believed that there were better ways to assist students in accelerating and changing their study methods.
To me, a great educator inspires dreams, encourages creativity, builds confidence and instils a love of learning providing a solid foundation for success as lifelong learners.

With that in mind, I created a campus where we the teachers, showed real passion and genuine desire to understand and help develop students’ abilities. Today we have over 65 campuses across Australia and New Zealand; our coaching colleges are staffed by the most knowledgeable educators who all share the same values in providing our students with highest standards in professionalism and ethics in all our activities as coaches. More importantly, we thrive on the connection we build with our students, to help them get their study processes right from the start of their journey with us.

From the time you call us on the phone wanting more details about our courses till when the student graduates, we assure you that your child and your family goals for their education becomes our key focus. We believe in succeeding together and growing stronger together.

As a parent myself, I know it takes a lot for parents to provide children with the best opportunities and possibilities. That is why I often reinforce to our students the “gratitude” mindset to remind students always to be grateful to parents for their unconditional love and support in their success.
I look forward to welcoming your family to North Shore Coaching College, where we will work together in helping your child to be the best they can be.
Chairman & National Principal, North Shore Coaching College

“Welcome to North Shore Coaching College, one of Australia’s largest colleges, delivering “Tuition that Works” to thousands of NSW, VIC, QLD, WA, ACT and SA students each year. We are delighted with our many success stories from students past and present. Our student testaments show our dedication and success in this field. Thank you to all the support from our students, parents and teachers since 1991.

With a vision to be one of the leading international education institutions specialising in coaching and tuition for students aged from 3 to 18, we are continuously offering new courses and competitions to ensure students are well prepared for their educational journey ahead. We want parents to be confident of the quality of all services provided as these core values underpin our educational goals.”
National Managing Director, North Shore Coaching College

North Shore Coaching College is Australia’s leading institution specialising in coaching and tuition with over 65 campuses across Australia. Established since 1991, we have been delivering high quality, affordable educational services with no hidden cost and no additional costs on booklets or test materials, for students from junior to high school.

We focus on ensuring our student learning ‘process’ is optimised. At North Shore, we assist students to develop effective time management, self-motivation and self-direction in studies which increases discipline, confidence and communication skills. Our goal is to prepare your child to be ‘results-oriented’ with an exam focused mind to succeed!

We use “Face to Face” teaching methodology with approximately two thirds of the time is spent teaching and the remaining is for class practice and individual attention which encourages creativity, open discussion and lateral thinking. We have PROVEN SUCCESS STORIES delivering "Tuition That Works". Many North Shore students achieve in winning school scholarship and gaining entry to selective high schools, gifted and talented programs, and moving on to distinguishing themselves at Australia's most respected universities.

conducted by highly qualified and experienced teachers. All aspects of the theory is covered with many illustrated examples and answers are provided. In addition to explaining concepts and work through examples, teachers also provide constructive feedback to students regarding their core abilities and knowledge required to succeed in exams.

“Just like a student would go for extra coaching to excel in sports, they can also excel academically through effective educational coaching.” – Mr Andy Mak, Chairman & National Principal, North Shore Coaching College

We continue to offer FREE Education Seminars at our Principal Campus in Chatswood, to give parents a greater understanding of important educational topics and issues, and to allow parents to better plan for their child’s education. Our Education Seminar is especially suitable for parents of Year 3-5 students who are unsure about how to complete the Opportunity Class (OC) placement application, the Selective High School placement test forms, how to select schools, and importantly how to best prepare for the placement tests, scholarship tests and more.

Our next FREE Education seminar will be held on Saturday 14th March 2020 at our Principal Campus. This upcoming seminar will have more of an Opportunity Class (OC) focus and will be available in 3 languages – English, Cantonese and Mandarin. We will be running 3 sessions on the day:
Register today to attend one of our FREE Education Seminar sessions!
Did you know that the SWAT exam results were also used to select entry into North Shore’s highly competitive Year 4 Young Achiever and Year 5 High Achiever Programs?

In 2019, North Shore Coaching College offered 80 top achieving students generous scholarships to study in 2020 at one of our NSW campuses. Congratulations to the 80 students across Years 3 and 4 for their success in SWAT, we look forward to welcoming you to study at North Shore in 2020!
Will you be the next SWAT success story?

The Selective Written Assessment Test, or SWAT, is a 4-hour ‘big hall examination’ experience that occurs annually and is aimed at helping Primary school students in Years 3, 4 and 5 prepare for the Opportunity Class (OC), Selective High School Placement Tests and Scholarship exams.

For Year 4 and 5 students, the SWAT exam consists of four papers in English (Reading), Mathematics, General Ability and Writing for Years 4 and 5. For Year 3 the SWAT exam will include two papers, testing in Writing, English (Reading), Mathematics and General Ability.
Registrations for SWAT will open in early-2020. In the meantime, register your interest below.
Purchase Practice Test Papers for Exam Preparation Books for Years 3, 4 and 5 by North Shore Coaching College, and many other educational resources, at the North Shore Shop.

ICAS Assessments will be available in
ICAS Assessments are tailored to current international curricula and use a broad range of methods to provide an objective, external benchmark of student progress. These

assessments are designed to recognise and reward academic excellence. Students are asked to demonstrate a deeper, integrated, and thorough level of learning. To ensure an engaging and beneficial experience for all students, new ICAS assessments are developed annually for each subject in every year level.

Results will be delivered via UNSW Global’s online reporting system and tracking student progression will be available to students and parents. All students will receive a downloadable Certificate of Achievement.
For more information, please visit the
Register your interest for 2020 ICAS Assessments held at North Shore Coaching College.
Purchase ICAS past papers, and many other educational resources, at the North Shore Shop.
The highest scores achieved by North Shore Coaching College students will be recognised by a special award to be given at the discretion of the Principal.

North Shore Coaching College offers past papers which may be purchased to assist your child in preparing for the ICAS Assessments. These past papers provide a valuable opportunity to gain test experience whilst acquainting candidates with the style and content of possible question types. Did you know that three North Shore students were ranked in the Global Top 10 for SEAMO in 2019? Congratulations to Bright Hu (ranked 2nd), Lenis Wu (6th), Evan Yiran Yang (6th) for their success in Paper B, and to Tyson Lieu (4th) for his fantastic result in Paper C.
Will you be the next SEAMO success story?
We are proud to announce that North Shore Coaching College is an
authorised Southeast Asian Mathematical Olympiad (SEAMO) Testing Centre.

This Mathematical Olympiad assesses the highest levels of creative thinking and logical reasoning. It provides guidance for the development of critical thinking skills that are required to excel in school and in the workplace.
SEAMO is open to students aged from 7 to 18 years old. North Shore Coaching College will be offering SEAMO at Chatswood and selected campuses in Spring 2020 for a registration fee of $20.
The test format will be a 1.5 hour written exam which includes 25 questions in multiple choice and written response format.
All students will receive a certificate and high achieving students will have an opportunity to perform at SEAMO-X in early 2021.
Registrations for SEAMO will open in mid-2020. In the meantime, register your interest below.
Purchase SEAMO past papers, and many other educational resources, at the North Shore Shop.
If you would like to prepare further for SEAMO, you can purchase workbooks and past papers at the
North Shore Coaching College offers SEAMO to all students,
providing that they will NOT be sitting SEAMO at their school or any authorised SEAMO testing centre.

We are proud to announce that North Shore Coaching College is an Authorised Testing Centre for the Computational & Algorithmic Thinking (CAT) Competition, administered by the Australian Maths Trust (AMT), which is under the Trusteeship of the University of Canberra.
The CAT has four divisions: Upper Primary (Years 5–6), Junior (Years 7–8), Intermediate (Years 9–10) and Senior (Years 11–12).
Most students will sit the paper that corresponds to their school year, but this is not compulsory.

The CAT competition is a one-hour problem solving competition designed to encourage student curiosity and promote multiple modes of thinking. Neither teachers nor students will need computer programming ability, but the competition will help identify students’ computer programming potential—something that they might not normally have the opportunity to demonstrate.

The competition is an ideal activity to encourage students to solve real-world problems. It is suitable for all students as it enables them to become more confident and willing to take on new challenges. The competition has a mixture of multiple-choice and integer answers and incorporates unique ‘three-stage tasks’ that encourage students to develop informal algorithms and apply them to test data of increasing size or complexity. The original problems are designed to be quick to solve and highly approachable, and range in difficulty from very easy to challenging. Some questions test the ability to perform procedures, others require logical thought, while the more challenging problems require the identification and application of algorithms.
Enrol now for CAT 2020! Select a test date and the number of tickets you would like to purchase, then click
for directions to North Shore House.

Many of you will have heard about the
. In this article, we explain what an OC is, how to apply, and how to prepare for the Opportunity Class Placement Test.

Opportunity Classes are classes in selected government primary schools catered especially towards gifted and talented students in Years 5 and 6. By bringing together bright minds and using specialised teaching methods, Opportunity Classes create a more suitable learning environment for high performing students. You can read more about OC on the
official NSW Department of Education website

Entry into Opportunity Classes is currently decided on academic merit using scores from school assessment and the Opportunity Class Placement Test. To apply for Year 5 placement in the following year, Year 4 parents must submit an application (usually around May) and have their child sit the placement test (usually around July).
Parents can choose up to two school choices, with the first one being the first preference. There are currently

offering Opportunity Classes, mostly with around 30 places each, so there are about 2,000 places in the OC system each year. Over 12,000 students sit the OC placement test, so only the top 15% (roughly) will be accepted into OC. You can view the minimum entry scores for schools’ Opportunity Classes
to read more about the application process. You can also come along to one of our
to learn more about applying for OC, Selective High Schools, Scholarships and other educational topics.

It’s never too early to start thinking about boosting your child’s academic journey, and it’s never too late to make a difference by supplementing their education with external coaching. That said, it’s generally more effective to work consistently over a longer period of time than (just) to prepare intensively in the lead-up to examinations. If you think your child would benefit from regular, personalised learning outside of school, weekly tuition might suit you.

In terms of the OC test specifically, around Year 3 is a good time to begin preparation, giving your child approximately a year to develop their knowledge and skills. A small number of sample tests are available from the
, but the best way to prepare is through North Shore Coaching College’s

Fastrain programs. We provide expertly developed courses focusing on English, Mathematics, General Ability and Writing (the four components of the OC test). FREE mock tests & review sessions are regularly provided as part of the Programs, as well as personalised homework help, additional exam preparation workshops and the

It is well established that preparation improves performance in the Opportunity Class Placement Test, and that schools do not provide preparation specifically for the OC test. Entry to Opportunity Classes is highly competitive by nature, but coaching gives students an edge by developing critical thinking and problem solving skills that will be useful throughout all of their schooling — even if your child misses out on Opportunity Class placement. Education is an investment in your child’s future, and here at North Shore Coaching College we take the responsibility and privilege of nurturing young minds very seriously. In providing
our aim is to set your child up not just for the OC test, but for a lifelong learning journey.

Writing for Exam Success is an essential course for students in Years 4-6 seeking to maximise their marks in this notoriously difficult section of the Selective and Scholarships placement tests. Developed and taught by experts, each lesson focuses on the specific criteria and ideas that examiners see as crucial to quality writing. To secure your spot or for more information, call 02 9415 1860 or your local Campus Director.
Please note: This course is only available in Terms 1 and 4 for 10 weeks per term.

Many of you will have heard about the NSW Opportunity Classes (OC). In this article, we explain what an OC is, how to apply, and how to prepare for the …

Albert Einstein was once asked what we could do to make our children smarter. He answered, “If you want your children to be intelligent, read them fairy tales. If you want them to be more intelligent, read them more fairy tales.”

Interestingly the research backs Einstein’s response. The more we read to our children, the greater their vocabulary. The greater their vocabulary, the better they do at school. The better they do at school, the more successful they will be in life.

A 2013 study by the University of Melbourne followed more than 4,000 Australian kids from pre-school to mid-primary. The study found the single-most-important predictor of overall success at school was the amount they were read to as toddlers. Reading to Young Children: A Head-Start in Life, found children who were read to three to five times a week were almost six months ahead of their peers in reading and cognitive skills (activities of thinking, understanding, learning and remembering) by the time they started school. Children who enjoyed daily story time were almost 12 months ahead. By age eight to nine, these kids recorded higher scores in the National Assessment Program – Literacy and Numeracy (NAPLAN) tests than kids who went without. In addition to the purely academic benefits, children who were read to regularly as toddlers showed greater school readiness, a better approach to learning and better physical, social and emotional development.

“It’s likely that strong reading ability will enable children to absorb and understand new information, which affects their achievement in all subjects,” says study co-author Dr Alice Sullivan of the 2013 British study; Social inequalities in cognitive scores at age 16: The role of reading.

We recommend making time to read to your child in a pleasurable environment, as it creates a happy association with books that can help motivate children to keep trying when the learning gets tough. Read to your children for 10 minutes every day. You can read to your child when you cuddle them to sleep, when they need comforting, while you’re having a coffee break or on Skype from your hotel room on your next business trip. Read food packaging labels in the supermarket queue with your child, the next time you shop. We all lead busy lives but reading to your child doesn’t need to be a chore. The value of reading to your child is evident in the ability to improve their vocabulary.
Inspired by an article published in CHILD Magazines on 11 February 2019

Many of you will have heard about the NSW Selective High Schools system. In this article, we explain what Selective schools are, how to apply, and how to prepare for the Selective High School Placement Test.

Selective High Schools are specialist government schools catered especially towards gifted and talented students in Years 7-12. By bringing together bright minds and using specialised teaching methods, Selective Schools create a more suitable learning environment for high performing students. You can read more about the Selective school system on the

Entry into Selective Schools is decided on academic merit using scores from school assessment and the Selective High School Placement Test. To apply for Year 7 placement, Year 5 parents must submit an application around October, two calendar years beforehand. Year 6 students sit the placement test in March, with offers sent out in July. Please see the table below for the key dates of the 2021 Selective Schools application/placement process.
Parents can choose up to three school choices, with the first one being the first preference. There are currently around

across the state, with about 4,200 places available in total. In 2020, almost 15,000 students sat the Selective High School Placement Test, so only the top 30% (roughly) will be accepted into a Selective School. Choosing and ranking three Selective school preferences is thus an important decision, the complexities of which cannot be covered in a short blog post like this. Not only do families need to consider travel times, academic rankings and school environments, but they must also make a judgment about their child’s ability and the likelihood of getting into particular schools.

where you can learn the ins and outs of the Selective application process, as well as other educational topics. Furthermore, our mock tests and exam preparation programs are a great way to gauge your child’s performance trajectory, with comprehensive results reporting included.
to read more about the Year 7 application process. For Years 8 to 12, there is a different process for Selective school entry. You can read more about it on the

For many families, the Selective test is the culmination of years of hard work, setting students up for an exciting and challenging high school experience. It’s never too early to start thinking about boosting your child’s academic journey, and it’s never too late to make a difference by supplementing their education with external coaching. That said, it’s generally more effective to work consistently over a longer period of time than (just) to prepare intensively in the lead-up to examinations. If you think your child would benefit from regular, personalised learning outside of school, weekly tuition might suit you.
A small number of sample tests are available from the
, but the best way to prepare is through North Shore Coaching College’s

Fastrain programs. We provide expertly developed courses focusing on English, Mathematics, General Ability and Writing (the four components of the Selective test). FREE mock tests, personalised homework help and review sessions are regularly provided as part of the Programs, as well as additional exam preparation workshops and the

It is well established that preparation improves performance in the Selective High School Placement Test, and that schools do not provide preparation specifically for the Selective test. Entry to Selective schools is highly competitive by nature, but coaching gives students an edge by developing critical thinking and problem solving skills that will be useful throughout all of their schooling. Education is an investment in your child’s future, and here at North Shore Coaching College we take the responsibility and privilege of nurturing young minds very seriously. In providing
our aim is to set your child up not just for the Selective test, but for a lifelong learning journey.
the 2020 Selective test will be in a similar overall format
to previous years, with some minor changes such as a better balance and variety of question types, the Selective Schools
application and assessment process will be overhauled in 2021.

At North Shore, we pride ourselves on our expertise, with decades of experience preparing students for the Selective test and beyond. However, we also recognise the need to adapt to changes in the educational system. The NSW Department of Education has released a

, flagging major revisions to the application and assessment process from 2021. This could include a stronger weighting on English skills, increasing the difficulty of the test, and reducing the predictability of the types of questions. We are monitoring these changes very closely, and our teachers and curriculum developers are ready to adjust our strategy as necessary in order to provide the best educational services possible – developing critical thinking and problem solving skills relevant not only for the Selective test but for a continuous, lifelong journey of learning.
If your child will be sitting the Selective test in 2021 or onwards, keep an eye out on this blog for further updates as more information about the new test format becomes available.
